content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								The gameplay actually has some good mechanics to it that make you feel in control of what is going on, which allows you to get better instead of get lucky. The idea of losing your items and cash when dying, but not your unlocked skills is really interesting.Now, as an early access game, here are some bugs/issues that I think the devs should glance at:-The graphics leave something to be desired though, such as unity's new soft shadows and maybe even actual PBR.-You can grapple a dead biker's unmanned bike. I discovered this because my push to talk button on teamspeak is the same as the grapple button.-You can easily exploit the "place me on track" button as it only removes your health and doesnt make you wait for the 5 seconds that crashing normally would. I think this button should emulate you crashing your bike instead.-General optimization issues, I get the same framerate on lowest graphics that I do on highest.-When starting the game with the music turned all the way down, some strange piano song plays and then suddenly cuts out.-Additionally, when starting the game it gets stuck on a light blue screen (similar to the color you see on the background of the unity logo), maybe this could be changed to show a loading image instead?-When switching out weapons at the beginning of the mission, it would be useful to see the durability of my current weapons.-Having a borderless windowed mode would be neat-The road is too visually flat, you can tell by the specularity from the sun-I think that there should be a bit of a minimap, similar to what you already get when racing, on all modes so you can tell whether you should back up or keep going if your goal is to kill cops/bikers.-When I saw the word "procedural", I imagined endless races that would randomly change, which I didn't get. Not too bad, but an endurance mode would be interesting with impromptu races and objectives.-Additionally with the procedural stuff, I feel theres not enough variation with each "biome". Maybe add more buildings? Some decals on the road?Either way, it's a great game, has some real solid gameplay to it, and worth the buy if you like fast paced racing games.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is a lot of fun. especially for one still in early access. If you are a fan of the Road Rash games, then this is for you. There were a few concerns when i started playing, like the addition of guns. You'd think theyd be highly overpowered amd overused, but it's actually quite balanced. Try aiming the camera sideways and not driving into a car or off a cliff. Even at distance, it's difficult to get a shot further than maybe 40 ft. There's also a rather unique Harpoon gun that can be used to spear opponents or, if you're crafty, launch it into a wall or the ground to slingshot yourself. Think Spiderman on rooftop levels.One bit of frustration I came across were some of the bugs. There was one in particular where, if you hit something while turning at high speed, it would just turn you in the wrong direction. In a race/ timed event, that's devastating. There is another where, when striking an opponent, your weapon simply passes through without damaging. The last one I can think of tends to happen on the rooftop races. Your bike will slow or stop the moment it's about to go airborne, or as it lands.Overall this is a lot of fun to play. The campaign mode is short at 12 levels, but it's harder than it looks to make it to the end. There are few level backdrops at, I think, 4. I look forward to seeing more out of this and maybe another couple of modes added on.

Whether you've played the old game Road Rash or not, this game is really easy to learn and pick up and play. Don't expect any story (yet?) but do expect to have a lot of fun smacking people with weapons and slamming them into cars and kicking them off cliffs! The game allows you to be as brutal as you can be and allows you to use your imagination a little.Pros:- Pick up and play- Fun combat- Fun racing- Hilarious ways to kill and die- Progress after death- Future online multiplayerCons:- Poor local multiplayer (enemies don't seem to spawn behind players, so whichever player is ahead is the only one who has fun)- Controls can be a little tricky/awkward- Small vehicle/driver selection (but is expanding)- Might be repetetive so some people?- Odd bugs (to be expected, however, since this is Early Access)9/10 for simply being a fun game to play. Looking forward to updates and added content!

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								I initially fell in love with this game. Like most others who have purchased it I compare it to the old Road Rash games. It's a great concept, feels good to play, and is a lot of fun in short periods. The problem, at least for now however, is the lack of content and depth. Sure you have the skills/perks to upgrade, but it seems to happen far too quickly. Maybe the solution to this would be to incorporate certain perks/skills that can only be unlocked on the more difficult bikes. It'd certainly give me a reason to attempt to play through the game on the more difficult bikes. It would also be cool to be able to upgrade bikes/purchase new bikes if implemented correctly.Also the number of tracks/environments seems quite stale. I know it's Early Access and this will hopefully improve with time. If things were my way I would have a track selection (See Road Rash 3 on Sega Genesis) instead of working up a ladder of random tracks. That being said the concept of having a random course for each track is cool. Multiplayer isn't really an issue for me, however a lot of the reviews and people I've talked to would have enjoyed it.Overall if you're looking for a bit of fun with combat racing, or want something similar to the old Road Rash series definitely check this out. Just don't expect something that will last in its current form, as unfortunate as it is to say this.TL:DR - It's a great game, although very light on content, and rough around the edges.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								Road RedemptionMay I start by saying that I loved playing Road Rash back in the day on the Sega Genesis? This game brings back memories of that time, but while being quite different. This game was obviously heavily inspired by Road Rash, and even has some of the same developers working on it. The gameplay is quite identical but with a few key differences.1. There are guns in the game. These are quite powerfull and fun to use.2. The bikes can have jetpacks and grappling hooks on some levels.3. Some levels are spent racing on rooftops. - Some people love this, some hate it.4. There are even crazy levels with cars raining down from the sky.This game doesn't take itself seriously at all. And can get quite wacky at times, but I love it.The game is quite short, you can beat it in about an hour. Though it has quite a bit of replay value.So don't think of that as the end of it.This game is early access, so be warned, it will change. And it doesn't always run perfectly.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Just watch the video and see what you can do. Doesn't that carnage, that sheer violence you can wreak on fellow racers look satisfying?I know nothing about Road Rash. I only know that this game makes pounding and shooting other bikers fun. The racing is a nothing, the front end is ugly as sin, the game design is an attempt to marry per-game style shopping for bonuses with modern indie roguelike persistent levelling buys. I don't think that element will work well in the long run but this isn't a game you play because it is a piece of solid design. You play right now for the wonderfully realized brutal fun of clubbing other bikers.It's ugly, it's wonky, not everything fits together right and may never will, but dangit, they got the feel of motorcycle racing violence right. The actual mechanic that will give you value on your dollar has received all of their attention and it shows all of that love.Watch the video, trust me. That's the best aid you're going to get for your buying decision.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								An early access game I've been with since the beginning thats shaping up really nicely, its a modern take on the old 'Road Rash' series which is a ton of fun to play.The game does still have a few bugs in it (nothing major though) but the developers are constantly updating the game and are very active in the game discussion forum which is great to see also.Gameplay wise the game is loads of fun, whacking your opponent with a bat or kicking them into the path of an oncoming car is very satisfying. There's not much in the way of modes or bike options yet although the developers have promised more of these will added and there's enough already there to warrant buying the game as it stands.My only gripe with the game so far is the 'car rain' levels, where, exactly as it says on the tin, cars drop from the sky in droves and bounce all around causing you to constantly and unfairly crash. As it stands its pure dumb luck that gets you through these unscathed and it would be better suited added to some kind of extra mode and removed from the main campaign in my opinion.All in all this is a fantastic game with lots more improvements and content to come, I highly recommend you buy it.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								Oh my god. This game controls like garbage.Now, hear me out. The gripping between the motorcycle and the road (even at its highest level) feels like the ice levels of Mario brothers. I keep sliding all over the place, which wouldnt be so bad if you weren't going so fast in the game.It has a system set up where you can duke it out with the other racers, but the map flies past you so fast that if you take your eyes off the road for even a second, you will either fall off the side, crash into a car, or crash into an obstacle.The races are so broken. Again, everything goes so fast that if you crash once, you are right back to last place, even if you were in the top 3 places. And don't worry, you're bound to crash into something, or better yet, an oncoming car will go into your lane and crash into you.For some reason you stick to everything you touch. Appearently everything, from the cars to buildings, are drenched in super glue, which means that everytime you hit something, you have to come to a complete stop and reverse to unhook yourself. I've even had a few times where I took out an opponent and the unmaned vehicle drifted in front of me, stuck to me, and caused me either to crash, or have to come to a complete stop and reverse to get out. (If this is not a problem that you are experienceing then it just might be me for some reason and you can disregard this point)Even if you DO see something coming your way, everything is moving so fast that you have little to no time to react, which means that you crash anyway.Say what you will about Burnout games, at least they made it so that you can go a fraction of a second looking at a spot on the screen, other than directly ahead, and not instantly die.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								I am giving this a thumbs up in the hopes that it evolves into something great. I was a huge fan of the Road Rash games and played each one on the Sega Genesis (1, 2 and 3) and I am hoping this game will pick up where they left off. Unfortunately this game is definitely as advertised and is not anywhere near complete. Things that need improved: The ability to freeride and explore. There is no point in procedural generation if you just set a cliff 20 bike lengths away from the road that leads to instant death when I approach. Bikes + Individual Parts to upgrade - this is by far the most shocking thing not yet implemented. Even Road Rash 1 had multiple bikes. RoadRedemption has a little upgrade meter but there is no info given. I am going to assume this a major placeholder while they tweek the bikes. Character customization: again shocking its not available even in early builds. They added a flaming pumpkin head which no one asked for but there is still no way to add a long flowing mullet to my character Framerate - even set to the lowest setting (which doesn't even render the yellow lines properly) the framerate drops like a rock when there is a car wreck, cops, and multiple NPCs on screen. If I am able to play AAA games like FC3, AssCreed3, etc. at moderate settings without a problem I should be able to play this at low settings at at least 15 fps. ...and much much more. I figured all this out in about 20 minutes. I hope the devs are working hard and make this a true sequel.

Early Access Review
								Road redemption is instantly fun. It has the core gameplay of Road Rash, though it could use a little polish in that area. Little things like holding back to do a wheelie and jump cars would really round out the feel of this game. However, the game truely shines when it comes to campaign advancement. You earn cash for races and spend it on upgrades for your current life. You earn XP that can only be spent after you die on permanent upgrades. Each race is a random objective, random environment status and random course. Ultimately you are trying to reach the final race without losing all your health. Combined this feels like a racing game I can keep coming back to for as many hours as I put in to FTL.What I still want: More polish (graphics and performance.) Improve the UI/add a tutorial (did you know you boost by double-tapping the gas pedal? I only found out through experimentation.) More maps. More Bikes. I would say more weapons, but there are already a plethora and they all feel interesting.Why you should buy this right now: Lever action slug shooting shotgun that you reload terminator-style

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								Oh my god. This game controls like garbage.Now, hear me out. The gripping between the motorcycle and the road (even at its highest level) feels like the ice levels of Mario brothers. I keep sliding all over the place, which wouldnt be so bad if you weren't going so fast in the game.It has a system set up where you can duke it out with the other racers, but the map flies past you so fast that if you take your eyes off the road for even a second, you will either fall off the side, crash into a car, or crash into an obstacle.The races are so broken. Again, everything goes so fast that if you crash once, you are right back to last place, even if you were in the top 3 places. And don't worry, you're bound to crash into something, or better yet, an oncoming car will go into your lane and crash into you.For some reason you stick to everything you touch. Appearently everything, from the cars to buildings, are drenched in super glue, which means that everytime you hit something, you have to come to a complete stop and reverse to unhook yourself. I've even had a few times where I took out an opponent and the unmaned vehicle drifted in front of me, stuck to me, and caused me either to crash, or have to come to a complete stop and reverse to get out. (If this is not a problem that you are experienceing then it just might be me for some reason and you can disregard this point)Even if you DO see something coming your way, everything is moving so fast that you have little to no time to react, which means that you crash anyway.Say what you will about Burnout games, at least they made it so that you can go a fraction of a second looking at a spot on the screen, other than directly ahead, and not instantly die.

content:

Early Access Review
								The game flat out right now I would give it a 7/10, recommended.  I will start out by saying the games graphics are really sick, you can even change the graphics to the old school look of road rash. Speaking of which, this games seems to be a complete reboot of the great game road rash that was on the N64. It is very simple, beat the absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥out of everyone around you, dont crash, and continue to go the right direction. I will start out by saying the graphics are beautiful, for the money I paid. The gameplay has a few glitches, but the chaos of other bikers and raining of cars was a lot of fun. Broad choice of weapons and upgrades is a plus, as well as getting a few of the characters to play as.Now, the few things that I have to complain about... I found a few glitches of my character dancing around on his bike and was not able to continue on the track to place, well, anything. The sword so far in the game has made it where I can not attack.. the skills are very easy to max out as well. I would enjoy to see online game play for this, a whole lot more of the bikes as well as characters and maps. This game has a lot of potential in it, I know its in Beta. I am looking forward to the overall outcome of this game! Overall, I recommend the game despite all the frustrating glitches. 7/10 is my review. Try it out yourself, its cheap as hell right now from these steam sales.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								I am giving this a thumbs up in the hopes that it evolves into something great. I was a huge fan of the Road Rash games and played each one on the Sega Genesis (1, 2 and 3) and I am hoping this game will pick up where they left off. Unfortunately this game is definitely as advertised and is not anywhere near complete. Things that need improved: The ability to freeride and explore. There is no point in procedural generation if you just set a cliff 20 bike lengths away from the road that leads to instant death when I approach. Bikes + Individual Parts to upgrade - this is by far the most shocking thing not yet implemented. Even Road Rash 1 had multiple bikes. RoadRedemption has a little upgrade meter but there is no info given. I am going to assume this a major placeholder while they tweek the bikes. Character customization: again shocking its not available even in early builds. They added a flaming pumpkin head which no one asked for but there is still no way to add a long flowing mullet to my character Framerate - even set to the lowest setting (which doesn't even render the yellow lines properly) the framerate drops like a rock when there is a car wreck, cops, and multiple NPCs on screen. If I am able to play AAA games like FC3, AssCreed3, etc. at moderate settings without a problem I should be able to play this at low settings at at least 15 fps. ...and much much more. I figured all this out in about 20 minutes. I hope the devs are working hard and make this a true sequel.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Oh my gosh this game is the stuff of legend. It's super early access as of writing this, and I already love it. The controls are tight and solid as a rock. The combat, while not as hard-hitting as Road Rash, is still implimented well enough to be vastly more entertaining that it should be. The tracks are all varied enough to keep my attention throughout, especially the current final track, that track may just be one of the best things to ever grace this genre.The thing that really gets me, on top of all the amazing gameplay, is the music. The music in this game is a step or two beyond phenominal. Even when cars come flying out of the air and send me on some sort of rocket ride to death-ville, I can't be even mildly upset, the tunes are just too good.With the promise of online play, this game can only get better and better. A rogue-lite, motorcycle racing combat game. That's just a beautiful combo right there.

All in all, the game is great so if you're on the fence then I would suggest getting it.

content:

								5/10I wanted to like this game...err did I?...in fact I may have been looking for an entirely different game altogether. Let me explain. I'm an older gamer (40) that remembers the original Road Rash games on the Sega Genesis. Back in the day, I loved these original bike beaters, and when I saw this - a blatant copy (or maybe homage?) of the original series, I just had to have it. I didn't ask for my money back, as firstly, I do like to support indie developers and secondly, I didn't want to admit I had made a drunken blunder and purchased this crappy game... Could be this can grow to become good, since I have no idea from where the development comes…. I can give it to the developer, the did capture the vibe, now they also need to add the soul….

number of helpful: 22 of 48 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Update (12-28-2014):  All the performance problems have been solved at the "Beautiful" setting.  It is somewhat playable on "Fantastic" even though the frames do dip.Notes: I have beat the game 12 times, gotten 12 of the achievements, and played on the most recent update (12-28-2014).  Reviewed on 3.5GHz i7 with 8GB RAM and a GeForce GTX 980, using the Xbox One game pad.This game was billed as a next gen Road Rash on Kickstrarter when I backed it back in May of 2013.  I received my steam key on September 18 2014.  I have played about 13 hours so far and I have to say I’m disappointed.  I hate to say it because I believe game developers are hardworking people and I understand it’s hard to create something and even harder to figure out what people (gamers) want.  If what is currently available is their vision for the game I wish them nothing but luck but it’s simply not for me.  The way the game works is you get cash, which converts into XP, for races and killing cops, enemy vehicles, and other bikers.- Even though it say it has random terrain generation I have seen the same road ways over and over to the point where I can tell when the finish line is coming without looking at the race progress bar.- The rainbow road and roof top levels should be hidden bonus levels at best.- Cars falling from the sky for some reason when you’re racing.  They updated this by calling it a "chemical hallucination zone" but it doesn't change the fact that it doesn't make sense.- Civilian cars going against traffic for no reason.- All melee weapons sound the same.  Even though that one sound is very satisfying.- Doesn’t feel like you’re in a gang.- Needs more melee weapons like a chain, Nunchaku, and maybe a whip?To me this is very unfortunate because when silly things, like cars falling from the sky, are not happening it does feel a a little like Road Rash.  I can’t imagine why instead of roof top they didn’t make levels based on real road ways.  It’s very scenic in some section of highway here in the US and this could have been imitated to great success. To the games credit there are some good thing like:+ The driving feels okay.+ The melee combat feels good.+ Some of the music is okay.Unfortunately I cannot recommend this game to somebody looking for something like Road Rash.

number of helpful: 18 of 40 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Well this game has riding a motorcycle, being able to hit other motorcyclists with weapons and being able to kick other motorcyclists. The similarities between this game and the old road rash games ends there. If you're looking for an actual modern road rash this is probably not your game, if you just want to hit people with things while riding a motorcycle you may like it.Performance is bad.Controls are not very good.The sound and music levels are off. Sound track doesn't really work with the gameplay. Sound effects sound like canned effects you could get for cheap off the net.Level design is bad to horrible. Why is there traffic driving on roofs going off the ledges like lemmings?, why make a grappling hook level when it's not interesting to use or fun. In some levels both lanes are head on traffic. What's with the tornado level, the level barely looks changed and all the level accomplishes is showing off how unoptomized the game is and creates frustrating no win situations. Are the random bombs in some levels adding that much to the game? It seems like a lot of stuff has been thrown in to be like "look how crazy we are!!". The core racing portion of the game is unsatisfying, it seems this game is more about hitting people with weapons.Enemies go from your standard motorcycle games to armored humvees. The car enemies in this game are the perfect anti fun!The upgrade system could have been interesting but the options are a little boring. More health, more ammo, more that stat, more this stat. Basicaly the same thing you will see in so many flash based upgrade games or rogue type games.

								I bought this game when it was understood to support multiplayer support. Multiplayer support means, at a minimum, over LAN or even better Internet. Local co-op sucks. I don't want my kids, wife, or anyone else using my gaming rig (I bought them all their own computers for a reason).Now that this game is headed to leave early access and Road Redemption Store Page shows only local co-op and single player  so I decided to write my reivew. Store Page does mention "Online mode coming very soon. " I'll revise my review after that option is supported.The game has zero replay value to me, friends, and family. I'm glad I only bought two copies (wife and I) that we both played for about 5 hours. I have already maxed out every option.Without true multiplayer this game is worth about $1. My friends and other 4 family members will not be buying copies.If this game adds multiplayer, then I'd buy 4 copies plus recommend to 4 to 6 friends who wait for me to recommend multiplaer games we'd play on weekends.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Second Edit: This game does not present itself well. The first hour is not very good. The starting areas are ugly and you start out with mostly combat, hardly racing at all. After an hour or so the environments get prettier and you can actually do some 'racing'.It's not exactly Road Rash either (I've got the Genesis version right here, and still play it), and the Kickstarter backers assuring you of that (and voting this down) are full of crap.  There's not enough racing for that, too much combat.Good stuff: The soundtrack is great. The combat is meaty and it's quite satisfying to take someone out. I do like the weapons (C4, boom!). The mission structure is interesting - it's basically a roguelike where you gain money from stage to stage and buy upgrades, but lose that all when you die. But then you can use your earned XP on permanent upgrades.  It gets prettier and less 100% combat after an hour or two.Biggest issues left: As noted, the first hour is crap and this needs a much better out of box experience. The physics are wonky as hell, pure 90s, which is fine for Road Rash, but then they pair it with a rooftop level that sticks bamboo slivers under the fingers of the wonky physics.  Also, the steering is still far too tuned for combat. You can't go off the road unless you're not paying attention, which makes the driving bit kind of boring.BUT The devs seem to have fixed the worst thing, which was a 180 degree camera rotation if you used the fast turn.  I'd switch from No to Neutral if Steam would let me. And I haven't asked for a refund yet.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
Early Access Review
The developer gave me a review copy - thank you to them, for that.Lets get one thing straight - this is a direct clone of Road Rash. It is also wayyyy too expensive for what it will end up being. But with that being said, its fun. There are permanent and run-based upgrades. There are different bikes with different attributes. There are different riders (Shovel Knight makes an appearance). There is night and day and different maps. Lots of different weapons, including guns.Pros:+As many flaws as this has, it is fun to cruise around and crank people with a tire iron+Music is actually goodCons:-Way too expensive, so get it on a deep discount-Physics is way wonky, it could use some more realism - like how I can fly off the road and fall into a valley and then super jump back on the road lolz-Graphics are super generic. Not sure if they are premade assets or what-Loading screens are bad, and remind me of PS1-Menus are clunkyIt is fun, but get it on a sale.

number of helpful: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								I am thoroughly enjoying this game.  Even though it is still Early Release Beta,  the game is incredible.  The graphics great, the fluidity of the physics and the AI makes the game fun to play.    If you come into the game thinking you will be mastering and making it to the end of every race without crashing, you are going to be disappointed.    A good chunk of the fun is watching the AI come up next to you, and somehow knowing  the perfect time to kick you off the side of the bridge or into oncoming traffic.  Reckoning back to this games inspiration, Road Redemption makes me laugh out loud at some of the crashes your rider goes through.   The multitude of weapons you can acquire adds to the fun.  A very entertaining piece of work.    Multiple thumbs up!

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								First you think: "Yay! A Road Rash follow-up!". Then it's fun for a few races until you realize how the game mechanics work. Opponents will never go full speed as long as you are behind them. Try overtaking someone they will immidiately blast up to full speed trying to knock you off your bike. It becomes too predictable in the long run. The best tactic is to stay behind the pack until halfway then try to use your nitro wisely and speed past everyone and avoid getting killed (which doesn't work very well either). Try to engage in a fight while going fast you will almost always end up crashing with an obstacle or finding yourself fighting with five other bikers you just overtook. I understand the game isn't meant to be realistic. But compared to Road Rash, this is just trash. All in all, good idea, poor execution. I don't think this game has any potential because the flaws are already too many. Total waste of money.

Early Access Review
								If this is supposed to be road rash then I suggest the developers start again. this game is so far from being fun. it has alot of "crazy" random events which doesn't really mask the shallow unchallenging gameplay, shoddy controlls and cheap ugly interface. I'm a huge fan of the original road rash games and I really wanted to like this. hell If the made a HD remake of road rash 2 I would buy that but this game is awful. the structure of the game is perhaps the worst thing about it. it's set out: win this race and continue or lose, spend you won points on stats and start from the beginning. This is not how to structure a racing/combat game. This is how to structure a rogue like dungeon crawler. The menu's and artwork are really bad they look like original doom/wolfenstein era menus only much less proffessional. If that hadn't tipped me off that perhaps this wasn't the game I thought I was buying then there's the handling which is sloppy and unwieldy but the price is the biggest insult of all. If this game were a shoddy road rage clone it might be worth the price to fans like myself but this game is lacking that (amongst many other things) which made road rash so memorable...fun

number of helpful: 1 of 9 people (11%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								I wish this game was better. I supported it, backed it on kickstarter, shared it with friends. The developers promised a Road Rash revival back in 2013 with a projected release date of aug 2014 for xbox 360, WiiU, and PC. What this game has become is a true disappointment. They developers have completely abandoned the xbox 360 and WiiU ports which they had specific backer tiers for on kickstarter with hundreds of backers. I have spoken to devs who have just let that fact stay quiet even while fully admitting privately that those ports are no longer possible. However despite the questionable ethics involving the kickstarter the game is still in rough shape in its existing form. This is not the Road Rash revival that you were hoping for. The game feels off, bikes feel like they are floating around on the road, there is no sense of impact or weight. The game is played entirely with weapons, there isnt even an option to throw punches against other riders, and ever rider is equiped with weapons. The "races" are full of endless spawned bikers that have no effect on the standing of the race. The rooftop races are a total disaster with bugs that will have you endlessly falling with no way to stop but quiting the race entirely, losing your progress. on top of the extremely mediocre execution of what should have been simple game mechanics the visuals do nothing to pick up the slack. I play the game on the highest possible settings and it is still pretty unimpressive, even for an early access game.to summarize this game is mediocre at best, and doesnt look like at has much hope of leaving early access. Its been almost a year since the projected release date and they do not even have this game functioning in online multiplayer, or have a finished single player campaign. I had originally written a less harsh review for this game, because I was still under the delusion that things would get better, but after closely looking over the timeline and having an extensive talk with one of the devs Ive decided to give up the ghost on this one. Maybe someday someone will fulfill on what this game promised... but I dont see that happening with Road Redemption. Buyer Beware.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								What's good about this is that's it's an interesting diversion, albeit one that's fun for only a few minutes. Gets quite annoying after that. Unless you're on the development team with access to god mode, apparently.What's not good:No Free Roam. Players need a way to just explore and try different stunts without having to deal with such an annoying campaign.Traffic randomly crossing the centerline and insta-killing a player.As noted above, no sign of procedural generation.Ramming the rear of a vehicle usually results in the camera being moved to where the player can't see where he's going.Crash detection needs lots of work. For example: player rides, and sinks, through some rock formations whereas others wipe him out by virtue of him just being nearby.No way of knowing where rivals and police are unless they happen to be in the player's field of view. Why no on screen map for this?Less than a minute to take down three rival riders on a twisty road without using weapons? Really?Whose bright idea was it to map Kick to B and Attack Right to Y? Shouldn't that be the other way 'round? Attack Left is X, one would expect Attack Right to be directly opposite at B!Why is there no mention of RB also being for Shoot Gun? Is there any way to aim a gun other than straight ahead?

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								I was a huge fan of this game until the recent update. That's right... it was updated. They didn't even bother telling anyone on the steam page this occured.  Notifying the fans who gave this game glowing reviews might have been on the list of priorities I think.  But, I digress -  I played the game about 25 minutes into this new update.  Some things I like, some major things I dislike.  Things I like: Graphics are sharper and more vibrant.No immediate problems with stabilityMy biker seemed to respond  better to my inputpick ups on track are  a neat additionThings I dislike:You threw your Wii U Kickstarter supporters under the bus with this update. Not cool. I don't care if there were only 2.Biker selection. What happened to the garage?My biker seemed to respond better to my input. Yes, I listed this as a both a positive and a negative.  The more responsive play control also made the game easier. Take kicking, for example. Before this update, I found kicking awkward and difficult to use. If I missed, I often ended up the victim, plunging to my death after my mometum carried me into a ravine. After this update, I was kicking dudes all over the track.  They were helpess against my size 13 boot to the face. I think on one track I killed everyone by kicking them. Even if weapons didn't degrade, there's no reason to use them.  Oh, wait....No more weapon degradation. I swear to God almighty I thought this was a bug when I first booted up. This is a HUGE change to a major gameplay mechanic. I'm going to elaborate on this a bit, so bear with me. Not sure who's idea it was to change this, but it was a stupid idea.  I assume it's the guy who leaves his phone number at the end of play sessions.  How or why this change made it through the development processes is anyone's guess, but it altered the entire game in a bad way and falls into that "if it ain't broke, don't fix it" category.  Here's one example of what it effects: the game has 50 or more weapons. You won't use a third of this content in a playthrough because there's no reason to get rid of good weapons you pick up. Not only did this kill some of the variety in a game that could use it anywhere it gets it (lets face it, the devs made a level where it rains cars just to give players something different), but it killed the difficulty as well. The difficulty was a selling point for me. I literally played through half of the available levels and I didn't have to cash in my experience once. I was too busy smashing skulls with a sledge hammer that never disappears. Before, I had to strategize which weapons were effective in certain situations and I had to keep those weapons fresh and ready for use. If I failed to have the right weapon, or my biker was too weak, I was screwed. Back to the XP to upgrade and maybe I'll get further next time.  It was like a game of chess. It was fun. It added to replayability by having to level up my biker to account for weak weapons. No one asked for this. No one thought weapon degragation was bad. No one believes that easier games are more entertaining. Replayability is gone. It's stupid. Change it back.That's it. There are other parts I could harp on, like no more Santa, but removing weapon degradation was a game changer for me.  I have no doubt other long time players feel the same way.No, I didn't spell check.

content:

Early Access Review
								Latest update made a HUGE difference. Game is a lot of fun and a spiritual successor to Road Rash in every way. Big thumbs up now. I want to recommend this game. I really do. I've played it enough to get to the end multiple times and max out my upgrades. There is a gem of a title in a VERY rough diamond in here somewhere. Gameplay is addicting and beating the crap out of other racers is very satisfying. However, there are several reasons why I cannot recommend this game right now, the main one being THE DAMN THING KEEPS CRASHING! I'm not talking occasionally. I'm talking 1 out of 10-15 sessions doesn't crash. It's super agravating and makes me want to remove the game from my library. There are many other bugs that detract from the enjoyment of the game as well (transparent items in the middle of the road making you crash when you clearly didn't hit anything). Someday, this game might be worth the money, but not right now imo.

Early Access Review
 Is a lot of fun,but there are problems that ruin it.Updated (fixes are crossed out)Overall performance has been increased,no longer randomly dropping frames which now makes the game smoother and guns useful.First the Pros:-When it gets fast,its a ton of fun.-Controls feel nice.-Has both permanent and temporary upgrades using different in game currency.-Said upgrades actually matter and will make you want to play more to unlock them all.-Only $20.But now the Problems...-Always driving straight into cars,since you go so fast and you cant see what ahead of you unless you tilt the camera up a bit constantly (which is annoying to do)-All A.I teaming up against only you-Enemies in cars will destroy you,pushing you into other cars to crash,but they are fine-Respawn is a bit long,crashed in 1st place,respawned in 7th-AI can time their bombs perfectly to blow up right in your face-Drops in FPS when it shouldn't (Playing with an GTX970,i7 4770,and 8gb ram)-Guns are useless,aiming and steering at the same time is impossible (played with both keyboard and controller)-No steam cloud,had to transfer save file with USB

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Important Note: Considering Road Redemption is still an early access therefore it is incomplete in my book, I am giving a review at it’s current state (after finishing the campaign, at 11/1/14.) Be warned if/when the game is fully released this review would be considered obsolete because it used an early build of the game than the full release review (I will make a second review of Road Redemption after the game is full fixed). Also the publisher provided me with a key to review. I will update this review once I play it againIncomprehensible Madness! Road Redemption(RR) is an action, racing, adventure, sports, indie, game, as such it’s quite frankly oddly reminiscent of old games I had played of mass destruction in vehicle warfare, to name a few how this game resembles past games are: Burnout Takedown 3/Paradise (Xbox/pc)Twisted Metal (ps1)Vigilante 8 (ps1)Veteran’s to vehicle mayhem will definitely enjoy their play through RR albeit short play through because the game isn’t finished yet. However it offers still a greatly satisfactory experience for mad car psychopaths or fresh newbie’s to sink their teeth into.Game play consists of bashing opponents with a melee/range weapons. Or kicking, punching, grabbing, etc. Across a linear map from point a to b. Or until you complete your objectives. Different modes of racing involve, taking down everyone, racing, specific objectives like kicking and grabbing only, and jumping waypoints (I suspect maybe more modes would come)The game offers a unique progression system that I haven’t experienced in past games of Twisted Metal or Vigilante 8. What it does, after you lose a race you have an allotted experience from which to input your points into; these range from more damage, more hp, nitro, cash, experience, etc. It even offers local co-op! And a new game plus and recently a Halloween mode. My only irritations to the game is the, dips in frame rate, linear tracks that only go straight and not open world. No mini-map (except a small A to B line of progression), Single motorcycle throughout whole play through, you can’t even switch vehicles to go into a car or a different motorcycle, speedometer is missing, you just alternate between accelerating, and decelerating, no retries to a certain level; meaning once you die you have to repeat the whole level again. So for example if you die during level 5 you have to restart at level 1 again. Phew. However, I would like to note the game is still in production and therefore the above mentioned could be added in later in the game (or not). And those irritations are just a matter of preference to me only.RR may appeal more to a group of friends casually playing against each other to 1-up each other, or someone who enjoys vehicle mayhem. I wouldn’t recommend this game to race enthusiasts because for one you can’t see the map or speedometer, as someone who enjoyed Burnout franchise and the other series I stated above, RR is a fresh change to vehicular mayhem in destruction. It even reminded me a bit of Red faction Guerrilla because of the amount of chaos you could create:Kicking people to walls,Throwing them off a ledge,Hitting a trailer full of logs to block enemies, Exploding innocent bystanders in vehicles,And so on....Overall, I enjoyed my time with RR, and although I would’ve liked more into it, I realize this game is still in Early Access, and therefore It’s still incomplete. I would recommend RR to any veterans of racers who love taking down their opponents, but would not recommend RR to casual racers hoping for the trophy after a certain amount of race completion. Although, if you like racing with a twist like mayhem perhaps this game is for you. But, most importantly I can see a huge amount of playtime delved into this game with a group of friends to mess around in. Or perhaps a newbie who just wants to try out a small game like this for his/her spare time.Regardless it’s really all up to you, how much you want to genuinely enjoy a game. With that said.Back and forth, you ride towards the night with caution written all over your face, the heart beats loudly inside of your chest. And yet outside only silence remains, but beware don’t look back, for you will lose yourself to the addiction of winning. Only with clear focus on the goal can you achieve victory. Impatience and Recklessness will only give you the start, and never the finish. Total Times Beaten: 1Legit: 1Score: 7.2 /10(Score is based off how much I enjoyed the game)(Legit is based off no cheating whatsoever, no guides, walkthroughs, video’s advice, etc.)Date reviewed: 11/1/14

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								ROAD REDEMPTION. A much improved Early Access ExperienceI originally reviewed this game in 2015 and gave it a bad review. At the time I appreciated that the game was very Early Access and could not recommend it.So what has changed?Well, in my original review I mentioned that there was no option for a quick race and at the time the game was distinctly lacking in certain areas. This now brings us to today's Early Access review. The game is still in Early Access state but has had significant updates from the developer. Included now is a Quick Race mode which is truly a welcome feature as many gamers would just like to have a couple of short blasts. I don't understand why every game these days just has to have a progression system but this game restricts it to the campaign mode only and I don't find it a grind like in many other games.With regards to the overall gameplay; Road Redemption is very much it's own game. It certainly is not a spiritual successor to the classic Road Rash games and if, like I, you puurchase this game with the sole purpose of replicating that experience then you will be disappointed.This game plays like a Mad Max on motorcycles. Pick your ride and lay wate in a post apocalyptic world of sorts. It is very much it's own game and needs to be appreciated that way.The inclusion of full 4 player local split screen is a very welcome addition, this is a game that cries out to be played with friends and I am hoping for online multiplayer to become a feature very soon.I must say that the devs have been very active in the community and I have had numerous messages exchanged with them regarding this game. This gives me a lot of encouragement that the game will be out of Early Access very soon and I am changing my original review from a negative to a positive.

								If you're looking for a spiritual successor to Road Rash,This isn't it.The simliarities between the two pretty much end at, "A racing game with motorcycle combat".The unity engine sucks. The sounds are weird. The animations are buggy and weird. So much makes no sense in the game. Robot people? Cars falling from the sky?If you were after a game like Road Rash where you simply rise through the ranks of a gang that YOU GET TO CHOOSE by racing in memorable locations, then you're not going to find it here.Admittedly this game is FUN but it should not be called a successor to Road Rash. Lacks ALL of the original charm and so much of it makes no sense what so ever.P.S Not to mention. Guns? Really? Why?

content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								With the new update, I have to change my review a bit. I'm more going to review the update than the game as a whole.Pros- Handling much improved- Combat feels more smooth and responsive than it has in the past- Music and sounds are getting better.- Visuals have improved marginally- I like the stage setup more and the little bit of voice acting gives more personality- The nitro is significantly improved. It's actually useful now.- Ability to keep more weapons is a plus.- Using the Critical hit on kicks is soooo satisfying.Cons-F*ck the F*cking God**amn hallucinagen zones.-I still hate guns in the game. It just doesn't add anything fun to the gameplay.-I'd almost like another way to trigger the nitro. Everytime I feather the gas into a corner, I go flying.Overall, I'm happily changing from Thumbs down to up. There's still room for improvement, but it's a huge step in the right direction. More bikes to choose from would be neat. Any sort of customization would add some depth. Having some allies instead of just neutral would make a player feel like they're in a gang too and not just solo.

								I would first like to say my friend got me this game last year around Christmas last year for a present. So where do I begin?Well when this game first came out, there was a lot of optimization problems with framerate and I don't think antialising was supported when it first arrived and they added it with a update along with all the settings and antistropic filtering, I'm giving this a thumbs up on it because this game reminds me of the old Road Rash 64 and the playstation 1 game and I love these type of games of riding a motor bike and wacking the bikers off as they try and kill you to get to the finish line. I don't play this game much but as a bordum I would recommend  this to anybody it's a fantastic game, the weapons in this game are fully loaded and there's a fall arsnal of guns, knives and c4 to do damage with and the optimizations of this game are all fixed, runs smoothly and is a great all round game in general. My computer specs are Processor, I7 6700 non k version skylake. My motherboard is the Asus Maximus viii itx board. and 16gb of ddr4 dominator  2100mhz. And my Graphics card is the Geforce GTX 980 4gb strix runs 1080p 60fps no problems.

Well if So, Just you wait. You've found the Mantra of Road Rash in a PC. Do you like games? Games with cars? Games with cars and Motocycles? Oh Yeah, Add Cops, Gangs and rooftops...Have I forgotten anything? ♥♥♥♥ yeah! But who cares? This game's legit. 2 legit in fact. I'd suggest it to my friends and enemies. Multiple Graphics settings, From Cheese to Please... it's got it all.  Beautiful is kinda hokey, but looks great until it poops out.Button Mashing asskicking shooting people with gernade launcer kinda fun. ALL DAY.Now mind you, this is still in alpha.. I think? if not, It's probabbly an EA game, but if it's just in Alpha, then it's just a glimpse of how awesome this game is really going to be. Someone slobbered on about something something +campain mode.. and extra gameplay.. but screw all that... You like your games like you like your women, Hardcore. So that's where +Campain mode comes in to♥♥♥♥♥♥all over your face again and again. I hope you brought a bib, cuz this game's gonna feed you your♥♥♥♥♥and make you beg for seconds. Oh yeah, cuz there is none. But who cares. This is a BAD♥♥♥♥♥GAME, No room for losers like multiplayer. This game is like masterbation, One on One. You Verses the chaos of a BAD♥♥♥♥♥GAME.Deal with it.90/100 ... Multiple Vehicle or more bike choices, Co-op and Online would make this 100.Would type all this again. and again.

Early Access Review
								This game has the feeling I've really missed since the NFS Underground games - aggressive, brutal, violent high-speed racing, even more so with actual weapons and motorcycles. It's certainly no release candidate at this date, but make no mistake - the driving, the combat and the sheer atmosphere of merciless gang rivalry is already nailed down.As long as none of that is lost, the game is a sure success, and I suggest you get it now JUST IN CASE something goes wrong at a later date. Highly recommended, an addictive roguelite bike action game with the balls to back it up.

Early Access Review
 Is a lot of fun,but there are problems that ruin it.Updated (fixes are crossed out)Overall performance has been increased,no longer randomly dropping frames which now makes the game smoother and guns useful.First the Pros:-When it gets fast,its a ton of fun.-Controls feel nice.-Has both permanent and temporary upgrades using different in game currency.-Said upgrades actually matter and will make you want to play more to unlock them all.-Only $20.But now the Problems...-Always driving straight into cars,since you go so fast and you cant see what ahead of you unless you tilt the camera up a bit constantly (which is annoying to do)-All A.I teaming up against only you-Enemies in cars will destroy you,pushing you into other cars to crash,but they are fine-Respawn is a bit long,crashed in 1st place,respawned in 7th-AI can time their bombs perfectly to blow up right in your face-Drops in FPS when it shouldn't (Playing with an GTX970,i7 4770,and 8gb ram)-Guns are useless,aiming and steering at the same time is impossible (played with both keyboard and controller)-No steam cloud,had to transfer save file with USB

content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
Early Access Review



YouTube™ Video: Road Redemption Playthrough | Road Rage! | Episode 1 

			Views: 75		

			Lead your biker gang on an epic journey across the country in this procedurally-generated driving combat adventure. Steam Link: http://store.steampowered.com/app/300380/ Please remember to like and...		

Road Redemption is basically Downhill Domination from the PS2, only on motorcycles. I used to be addicted to DD, so seeing this game on Steam made me super pumped, and I instantly bought it.  To skip reading my review, check out my playthrough below, otherwise, you can continue reading for more: RR is a fast paced driving game, in which you're racing on a motorcycle against AI also on motorcycles, cars, and other vehicles. The game offers multiple different options of motorcycles to drive, from the Honda CBR to various choppers, and even different riders to choose from. There aren't a whole lot of options, but maybe more will be added in time, since I haven't unlocked any through playing just yet. The gameplay is somewhat laggy/jumpy even on Fastest quality setting, but it is early access so hopefully that will be cleared up. There is also no multiplayer option available, but I'd like to see the game more polished before trying to add others just yet. However, there is a split screen option available which is very rarely seen, and which I have not tried out just yet, although I don't see any reason for it to be any more laggy than single player.  In order to use the split screen option, the other players must use gamepads. There are plenty of obstacles to avoid, such as other cars on the road, poles, and even falling debris on some maps, which add a nice challenge to the game. Swinging weapons and shooting guns are failry straight forward and easy, although the controls are somewhat confusing. In order to grab or kick, you must have your camera facing the direction slightly that you want to kick or grab, while swinging your weapon only takes clicking either the left or right mouse button. So far, I have seen weapons such as shovels, crowbars, long swords, magnum revolvers, shotguns, pistols, and more, so you won't get tired of using the same weapon. Timing on the weapon swings feels just right, and I have plenty of fun knocking other riders off their bikes, or smashing enemy cars to destruction.The controls of the bike are where the game is lacking most, as the turning is either too drastic, or not enough. I find myself overcorrecting myself too often, and launching myself off the side of the map. The turbo is a nice touch though, and helps with catching up. Also, if you completely fail, the other riders will never be too far ahead, allowing you plenty of time and chances to come back before the finish line. Each race has 3 different levels/maps that you must complete, and each race gets progressively harder and adds more content to the game. If you fail one of the levels, you must restart the entire race, but your previous races, progress, and skill points will be saved. There are plenty of skills and perks to choose from and purchase, from increasing bike speed, armor, health, weapon durability, and tons more! Overall, this game was tons of fun, and I enjoy it a lot! I look forward to what the developers have in store for the final product, and I will continue to play as they continue polishing and improving this game.

Early Access Review
								Well like many others before me said already this is the spiritual successor of Road Rash. So if you liked and played RR you will probably like Road Redemption. This game is so much fun. Lots of different melee weapons from spiked clubs over katanas to broadswords and C4. Different fireweapons ala AK47, shotgun, pistols and wth a ♥♥♥♥ing grenade launcher :D.  Other the that you can grep, kick your opponents and even use your ropethrower on them. So many possibilities for combat.Missions range from checkpoint races, to normal races, reach pursuit level and knock enemies out. Each time you start a game the missions are randomized to be not too repetitive.Ah well and the upgrade system is pretty good. But you are fast to get every point. Hope it will be extended.First time play for me was around December last year. Game was already fun and good looking but I had massive problems with the framerate (probably due to the Psysik effects) especially in the carstorm levels.With the last big summer update these guys fixed it completely (putting the Physics on multiple cores) and to top it off the even improved the graphics a lot and added new textures and racetrack enviroments.Now the game runs smooth at 2560x1440p at highest with my i7-4930k and Radeon 7970 GHz.I can only recommend this game as it is fun and the developers do their best (which is really good)  to improve the game for everyone. Kudos to you guys.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								As it is now, it's a pretty solid bike racing / fighting experience, in the spirit of the old Road Rash games, which is good because I loved that series and I've been waiting years for a game like this.Anyway, keep in mind that this is an Early Access game, so it's safe to pick it up if you're a Road Rash fan like me, you'll most certainly love it, but it is not a finished product. It suffers from the poor performance issues of Unity 4, so until devs update it so it will run on Unity 5, the most crowded moments of the game will seriously drop your FPS, but overall it's playable, so it's not that big of a deal, considering that updates are released pretty regularly and I think that the transition to to Unity 5 will be only a matter of time.Also, it currently lacks competitive multiplayer and online, so at the moment you'll be only able to play 2-4 players co-op. When competitive and online multiplayer comes out, it will be a great boost to the replayability factor of this game, which is already pretty high considering that the campaign is procedurally generated and the skill system along with the temporary upgrades that you can buy in the shop between races makes every campaign different from another.Procedurally generated tracks are generally good, but are not so varied and tend to get a bit repetitive really fast (expecially rooftop ones, and it's a shame considering that at first it's a really fresh and fun concept). Also you can't save tracks in any way, so even if you loved a track and want to play it again sometimes, or with friends coming over at your house, you currently can't. I hope they'll add an editor of some sort or even a seeding option to play around with the track generator and why not, share tracks with the community.Weapon variety and fighting are great, it's so funny to get rid of rivals by smacking them in the face with a spiked bat, grabbing them and ramming them into the upcoming traffic, or slicing them with a BATTLE AXE! Firearms are a bit OP obviously, this being a bike racing game, but they come with limited ammunition and if you like challenge, you can choose to not use them at all (but give the grenade launcher a try, it's funny as hell), since CPU rivals will not (save for a specific event in which there are some bikers with unlimited pipebombs). I hope they will be toned down a little when online and competitive MP will be added.At the moment there's not a large choice of bikes and characters, and there are no upgrades that change bike stats (other than damage resistance) or its appearance.So, to sum this review up, I give this game 7/10, only because it's clearly unfinished (after all, it is an Early Access game), and I recommend it to anyone who played any Road Rash and/or likes the concept of racing/brawling on motorbikes, and I recommend buying it in the meantime (consider buying it when it's on sale if you're not a diehard Road Rash fan or you're not sure you want to buy an Early Access game) to support developers, so updates will be released faster, and also because it's very likely that it will cost more when it will be finished. Also it's nice to see that devs take time to read our opinions and answer to them in the forums, so this is another good reason to buy it and play it so that your feedback will help making the game better and better. It really has potential, and with some tweaks here and there it could easily become the best game of its genre.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								Ok, this should be considered a "First impressions" instead of a full review, which should come later.Road Rage is fun. Yet unrefined. The first thing I noticed is that this game taxed my system pretty hard, while not looking all to great. I ran it on Medium-High with my rig, a GTX 760(2GB VRAM), an i3-3220, and 8GB ram, all while barley staying over 40FPS. Keep in mind, this rig runs damn near anything(Take a look at my Steam Games) on High with no problems. Anyway, it just didnt look too good. I also noticed a lot of clipping issues, along with some really soddy textures.Graphics aside, the game sounds pretty good. I loved the music, and all the sounds are pretty good.In the gameplay section, its pretty good. The goal is to win a race by any means nessesary. You will pick up guns, melee, C4, and anything in between to kill the other racers. All of them "Feel" good, and are all fun to use. All the "Maps" are pretty good, yet they are repeated way to often. Yet, my largest complaint comes with the games Xp/Cash/Single Player Elements. Ok, in short, all money is lost upon death, along with all items. Maybe this was a thing in the original game, but I'm a bit to young to remember back that far. I found this system quite annoying. But it wouldnt be so bad if the only way to level up was to die. I mean, the Xp system is vast and fun to explore, but...Also, maybe i'll get the hang of it, but the game just seems to lack any sort of coheasion as far as the SP element goes.Yet, I feel like this game could turn into something good, maybe great. I'll try to play more of it as time goes on. but just take the "Yes" recommendation with a pinch of salt.

								This game has a lot of ground to cover before it is worth the money. I see potential, I just hope the developers see the same. For instance, the physics; you'll have cars flipping out like crazy right at you.The collision detection is a bit lacking with enemies hitting you when they are swinging their weapon in the opposite direction, mind you, you are able to do this as well. The level progression is somewhat questionable, with randomly generated missions, leaving you up to the same task, with different tracks. That being said it does add some variety to the table. For those of you, like me, that enjoyed the classic Road Rash game on Windows 95, this game is quite similar. I do hope they add certain elements like being able to choose out of a variety of bikes. At the moment you just click on the upgrade bike button as it stacks up with the XP you gained.There is also a skil tree system implemented in the game. Along with an upgrade system that, with some time and balancing, will perfect out your racing style.An excellent game with excellent early access potential. They just need to iron out the bugs and tweak the already existing contentm before they think of implementing other features.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								I just finished my first run through the normal game mode and wanted to share my thoughts. Awesome game so far, and the devs. are updating it consistently!  One of the few early access games i would fully recommend.  Also, it's basically a full game,  only needs some minor work,  so grab it now before a price hike!  If you liked the old classic Road Rash, or sometimes wish you were able to bash other motorists without repercussion for poor driving, then this is your game. ProsEasy to pick up (Controller is HIGHLY recommended!!)  works great both m+k and controllerHuge Upgrade system. Each "run" you can upgrade temporary things, like increase in defense, more health, more stamina, etc.  After you die, you are then able to put your xp towards permanent upgrades like better starting bike/weapon, higher health, better starting weapon, etc.Varied race types such as Race, take down X number of baddies, time trial, only kicking and grabs, etc.Extremely fun and satisfying.  Every time i play i have a huge grin on my face, its one of those games that is just fun to pick up and playI have yet to have a crash or encounter any bugs.Room for improvementOnly a few locations (rooftop, desert, snow covered, and rainbow) could use one or two more. (Maybe a downtown, a suburban,  or a dirt race track)  Could use one or two more race types (Maybe like a tag style game where you have to bump another bike to "tag" it and the goal is to not be "it" when you cross the line, or something that incorporates your gang, like take down 5 baddies before they take down 5 of your gang.)Would be cool if you could actually name, customize and upgrade your bike gang in game.More use of your gang.  As of now it just feels like they are kind of getting in the way and not really all that helpful.  Would be cool if they actually followed/flanked you on some missions and were more active in taking down baddies.Posted 2/9/2015

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Update: I decided to change my feedback of this game from "not recommended" to "recommended". I actually had a chance to talk with the design team, and they were genuinely concerned with the comments I previously made. They have been contacting me asking if my previous issues have been addressed and after the latest update that was released on February 8th, 2015, the game is finally playable on my machine. I haven't encountered nearly as many game-breaking bugs as before either.Another thing I noticed with one of the recent updates is a "tip" to use "jump jets" when you are racing on the city rooftops. You can push the left bumper to hover up into the air to prevent falling to  your death. I didn't even know that there were "jump jets" in my initial review, which sort of gave me a "AH HA!" moment. I am still not a fan of the races on the rooftops, but to each his own I guess.Overall, the races are really fun and the team behind this game seem to take pride in their work. They are constantly improving the game and making it more stable on slightly older machines. My pc is a 4ghz quad core, 8gb RAM and I recently swapped out my graphics card with an Nvidia Geforce GTX 750 Ti 2gb. Keep in mind it's still an early access game, but they have finally polished it up enough to make it worth adding to your library.I also can't wait to see how the multiplayer modes turn out. If you are a Road Rash fan and want to get a quick combat-race fix, you should give this game a try.My older, original feedback/review of the game is below:------------------------------------------------------------------------I know this is an "early access" game, but it runs so poorly optimized on my pc that the game will run at 5 fps at certain points. I can run every  other game on my pc just fine and I have a decent graphics card (AMD R7 260x 2GB). The graphics are nothing to write home about, which makes me wonder where all of the wasted processing power is going. The game can be sort of fun when the frame rate is high enough, but even when I turn the settings to "fastest" and lower the resolution it doesn't help much.In terms of gameplay, it borrows many elements from Road Rash, but it has a "rogue style" element where you start over if you die, but can unlock additional perks at the end of each session. The levels are randomly generated, which adds variety, but this can also introduce game-breaking bugs. I had one level where you are racing on top of city skyscraper buildings and jumping from one roof to another. The only problem was the beginning of the race generated two building that were too far apart, making it impossible to land the jump across and finish the race.I don't hate this game, but at the same time I can't recommend buying it in its current state. I will update my review if some dramatic improvements are made to fix the frame rate issues and other bugs. The devs hearts are in the right place trying to make a Road Rash clone, but in the end it just makes me wish someone else out there could make a proper Road Rash sequel. This game feels too much like a rushed cell phone/tablet game than a proper console experience I was hoping for.

Early Access Review
								Review edited due to new updates. Firstly I want to say the dev added me and gave me a copy to prove how much better it is. My review is not tainted by this. I played the game for a bit being very cautious about it. Somehow after not enjoying the thing the first time I know find it quite fun.Pros: The controls are better, I feel like I can actually handle the bike (mostly). Graphics are a bit more appealing, things seem less straining on the eyes from the first time. I love the concept of it, a road rash like game was something I wanted since the second one. I do enjoy the new mission structure, it feels like a decent difficulty curve now. Most of my like for the game stems from what I (or you) would love from Road Rash.Cons: The constant desert scene is a bit draining on the eyes. Black/brown/yellow is not a great color pallet. The controls don't seem to meet a middle ground, sometimes they're too stiff and others they're too sharp. Levels seem to be similar each time, with only a couple mission modes it doesn't feel different. The game seems to lose a lot after you've bashed a person's head or decapitate them the 1000th time.Overall the game is quite fun, it's in a much better state then it was in months ago and if the devs show this much love I beleive it will be much better in the future. I thank you for giving me a copy to prove you're this much invested in the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								Let me say first that I played Road Rash on Sega, PC, and N64. Love Road Rash and so I was really looking forward to this game. There are great bones here. The strength of Road Redemption (in its current state) is in the gameplay itself. The riding and fighting are solid. I would like to see the overall game modeled more after the N64 Road Rash but it is still fun. There needs to be rivals and biker gang issues. Earning small amounts of cash and slowly upgrading weapons/bikes. Keep hit damage lower to encourage more and longer battles. Road Redemption is at its best when you are flying down highways, making turns and battling. Overall this is a great start to a full version. If you aren't a fan of Road Rash then this alpha probably isn't for you.Just adding to my review since my old one is from so long ago. Much of my initial review still rings true today.Bottom line is probably still the same. If you have extra cash and really enjoy motorcycle combat then you won't be disappointed. If you are on the fence I wouldn't buy it in its current state. I am going to stick with recommend for now but unless significant strides are made before a final release I will probably switch to not recommend.I can't remember the last time I had such mixed emotions about a video game. On one hand the riding and combat is pretty solid. Graphics are good. I think the frustrating thing is the lack of direction. Is this supposed to be a burnout style arcade game with lots of boosting and takedowns? Is it a more classic road rash based on racing and more of a simulation style? (I understand simulation of racing motorcycles while fighting sounds ridiculous but you know what I mean). The heavier bikes and less control in the air suggest sim. The decapitations and jump jets suggest arcade. It just seems to ride this akward line between the two. What is the long term hook? There is a good short term hook in that you won't beat the game initially and you want to get in one more run, make some progress, and get some upgrades. Just seems like there should be higher levels of difficulty you progress through like old road rash games that you could meld with the XP skill tree stuff. Get money, buy better (and faster) bikes and weapons which propels you through the lower levels, keep grinding. The game becomes more difficult with tougher AI and the natural difficulty that comes with racing at higher speeds. This is my number one complaint (along with chemical zones and even worse bombs being dropped in the middle of the road). I would like to see a long play game with save points instead of the current you died start over with you upgrades system. After the update my progress was wiped, which I had hoped for. I played a few nights and had beaten both the regular and campaign + modes. It was definitely less than 10 hours. Hadn't filled the skill tree out much. It was like 4 or 5 runs through and one of them I bombed out pretty early. Levels 3 through 10 or so is where the game really plays the best to me. Mostly hand to hand combat and lighter guns. Overall I think a lot of good things were done in the update but I just don't see this game being where I had hoped in the near future. If this were an earlier build and you had more time to flesh out a deep campaign I would be extremely excited for this game. When are you planning on calling this a complete full game? The end of the summer? There has been a lot of improvement from gameplay to levels to AI. Almost every facet has gotten better but I feel like at the end of this I am going to say it was a pretty decent little game that could have been great.That all said I spent $15 or $20 or something and have had quite a bit of fun. I have logged 23 hours according to steam. I have been waiting since road rash 64 for a respectable motorcycle combat game and that someone finally tried makes me happy. Just the fact you guys are doing what you want and making a video game is awesome. The multiplayer will definitely add something to the total package and I am sure I am not done playing road redemption. Just wanted to offer my honest opinion on the game so far. Wish you guys nothing but the best on this and any future games.*UPDATE*Just wanted to update my review. I am changing my review back to recommend. For the cheap price this is really a pretty solid game and I have definitely gotten my money worth over the last couple of years. Solid progress has been made. Looking forward to the actual release of the full game

Early Access Review
								This game has a lot of ground to cover before it is worth the money. I see potential, I just hope the developers see the same. For instance, the physics; you'll have cars flipping out like crazy right at you.The collision detection is a bit lacking with enemies hitting you when they are swinging their weapon in the opposite direction, mind you, you are able to do this as well. The level progression is somewhat questionable, with randomly generated missions, leaving you up to the same task, with different tracks. That being said it does add some variety to the table. For those of you, like me, that enjoyed the classic Road Rash game on Windows 95, this game is quite similar. I do hope they add certain elements like being able to choose out of a variety of bikes. At the moment you just click on the upgrade bike button as it stacks up with the XP you gained.There is also a skil tree system implemented in the game. Along with an upgrade system that, with some time and balancing, will perfect out your racing style.An excellent game with excellent early access potential. They just need to iron out the bugs and tweak the already existing contentm before they think of implementing other features.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								Ok, this should be considered a "First impressions" instead of a full review, which should come later.Road Rage is fun. Yet unrefined. The first thing I noticed is that this game taxed my system pretty hard, while not looking all to great. I ran it on Medium-High with my rig, a GTX 760(2GB VRAM), an i3-3220, and 8GB ram, all while barley staying over 40FPS. Keep in mind, this rig runs damn near anything(Take a look at my Steam Games) on High with no problems. Anyway, it just didnt look too good. I also noticed a lot of clipping issues, along with some really soddy textures.Graphics aside, the game sounds pretty good. I loved the music, and all the sounds are pretty good.In the gameplay section, its pretty good. The goal is to win a race by any means nessesary. You will pick up guns, melee, C4, and anything in between to kill the other racers. All of them "Feel" good, and are all fun to use. All the "Maps" are pretty good, yet they are repeated way to often. Yet, my largest complaint comes with the games Xp/Cash/Single Player Elements. Ok, in short, all money is lost upon death, along with all items. Maybe this was a thing in the original game, but I'm a bit to young to remember back that far. I found this system quite annoying. But it wouldnt be so bad if the only way to level up was to die. I mean, the Xp system is vast and fun to explore, but...Also, maybe i'll get the hang of it, but the game just seems to lack any sort of coheasion as far as the SP element goes.Yet, I feel like this game could turn into something good, maybe great. I'll try to play more of it as time goes on. but just take the "Yes" recommendation with a pinch of salt.
